root.pub-comments: The author posits this higher subgrouping, Proto-Arnhem, but also makes clear that the only definitive subgrouping is Maningrida. The other languages outside of Maningrida, while somehow related, show no clear subgrouping within Proto-Arnhem yet. Their inclusion in this tree is to demonstrate that the author believes there is a relationship, but beyond Maningrida, the subgroups are not clear or defined. "In a comment on my earlier paper, however, Evans pointed out that many of the irregularities which I was reconstructing for Proto Maningrida were also found in Mangarrayi. Mangarrayi, in fact, has cognates of both the Proto Gunwinyguan Past Punctual, and the Proto Maningrida Contemporary; it provides evidence for linking the Maningrida languages with the 'Gunwinyguan' languages. The same evidence can be found in Ngandi and Nunggubuyu, and in Marra, assigned by previous investigators (e.g. O'Grady, Voegelin & Voegelin 1966:32; O'Grady, Wurm and Hale 1966) to a separate 'Maran' family along with Warndarang and Alawa" (Green 2003: 370). "The present study focuses on twenty-four verbs which clearly demonstrate the relationship of all the languages under consideration, while also showing proof of the closer genetic relationship of the Maningrida languages" (Green 2003: 371). "While the broad picture clarifies the status of the Maningrida languages as a separate branch of the Arnhem family (?), it raises a new problem with regard to the other languages included here… This paper shows that much of what has been proposed for Proto Gunwinyguan verbs is attributable to the parent language of a much wider grouping of languages, which I have called Proto Arnhem... To what extent, then, does 'Gunwinyguan' form a distinct grouping characterised by identifiable innovations? And what other branches can be demonstrated on the same basis?" (Green 2003: 419). "Given the lack of a coherent picture of a deeper proto-level, it is unavoidable that genetic groupings proposed on the basis of shared morphology may actually turn out to be based on shared retentions from that higher proto-language" (Green 2003: 420).

child.pub-comments: "In this revised paper I will therefore present evidence which I believe demonstrates the genetic relatedness of a large number of languages of Arnhem Land: Burarra (Glasgow 1964, 1984, 1994), Gurr-goni (Green 1995), Ndjébbana (McKay 1980, 1981a, 1981b, 1981c, 1982, 2000), Na-kara (Eather 1990, forthcoming) (forming the Maningrida group); Mangarrayi (Merlan 1982), Ngandi (Heath 1978b), Nunggubuyu (Heath 1984) and Marra (Heath 1981). Some evidence from Kungarakayn (Parish 1983), Gaagudju (Harvey 1992), Rembarrnga (McKay 1975), Kunbarlang (Coleman 1982) and Warndarrang (Heath 1980) is also included" (Green 2003: 370).
child.publications: Green, Rebecca. 2003. Proto Maningrida within Proto Arnhem: Evidence from Verbal Inflectional Suffixes. In Nicholas Evans (ed.), The Non-Pama-Nyungan Languages of Northern Australia: Comparative Studies of the Continent's Most Linguistically Complex Region, 369-421. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 085883538

child.pub-comments: "In a comment on my earlier paper, however, Evans pointed out that many of the irregularities which I was reconstructing for Proto Maningrida were also found in Mangarrayi. Mangarrayi, in fact, has cognates of both the Proto Gunwinyguan Past Punctual, and the Proto Maningrida Contemporary; it provides evidence for linking the Maningrida languages with the 'Gunwinyguan' languages. The same evidence can be found in Ngandi and Nunggubuyu, and in Marra, assigned by previous investigators (e.g. O'Grady, Voegelin & Voegelin 1966:32; O'Grady, Wurm and Hale 1966) to a separate 'Maran' family along with Warndarang and Alawa" (Green 2003: 370).
child.publications: Green, Rebecca. 2003. Proto Maningrida within Proto Arnhem: Evidence from Verbal Inflectional Suffixes. In Nicholas Evans (ed.), The Non-Pama-Nyungan Languages of Northern Australia: Comparative Studies of the Continent's Most Linguistically Complex Region, 369-421. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 085883538

child.pub-comments: "In this revised paper I will therefore present evidence which I believe demonstrates the genetic relatedness of a large number of languages of Arnhem Land: Burarra (Glasgow 1964, 1984, 1994), Gurr-goni (Green 1995), Ndjébbana (McKay 1980, 1981a, 1981b, 1981c, 1982, 2000), Na-kara (Eather 1990, forthcoming) (forming the Maningrida group); Mangarrayi (Merlan 1982), Ngandi (Heath 1978b), Nunggubuyu (Heath 1984) and Marra (Heath 1981). Some evidence from Kungarakayn (Parish 1983), Gaagudju (Harvey 1992), Rembarrnga (McKay 1975), Kunbarlang (Coleman 1982) and Warndarrang (Heath 1980) is also included" (Green 2003: 370).
child.publications: Green, Rebecca. 2003. Proto Maningrida within Proto Arnhem: Evidence from Verbal Inflectional Suffixes. In Nicholas Evans (ed.), The Non-Pama-Nyungan Languages of Northern Australia: Comparative Studies of the Continent's Most Linguistically Complex Region, 369-421. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 085883538

child.pub-comments: "The four languages Ndjébbana, Na-kara, Burarra and Gurr-goni are non-Pama-Nyungan languages spoken in north-central Arnhem Land, to the east of the Liverpool River… The settlement of Maningrida is located in the country of Ndjébbana speakers, and it is the community with which most Na-kara, Burarra and Gurr-goni speakers are also associated. These languages are surrounded to the west and south by other non-Pama-Nyungan languages of the 'Gunwinyguan' family... and to the east by Pama-Nyungan Yolngu languages, the nearest being Djinang" (Green 2003: 369). "The present study focuses on twenty-four verbs which clearly deomonstrate the relationship of all the languages under consideration, while also showing proof of the closer genetic relationship of the Maningrida languages" (Green 2003: 371).

"In this revised paper I will therefore present evidence which I believe demonstrates the genetic relatedness of a large number of languages of Arnhem Land: Burarra (Glasgow 1964, 1984, 1994), Gurr-goni (Green 1995), Ndjébbana (McKay 1980, 1981a, 1981b, 1981c, 1982, 2000), Na-kara (Eather 1990, forthcoming) (forming the Maningrida group); Mangarrayi (Merlan 1982), Ngandi (Heath 1978b), Nunggubuyu (Heath 1984) and Marra (Heath 1981). Some evidence from Kungarakayn (Parish 1983), Gaagudju (Harvey 1992), Rembarrnga (McKay 1975), Kunbarlang (Coleman 1982) and Warndarrang (Heath 1980) is also included" (Green 2003: 370).
child.publications: Green, Rebecca. 2003. Proto Maningrida within Proto Arnhem: Evidence from Verbal Inflectional Suffixes. In Nicholas Evans (ed.), The Non-Pama-Nyungan Languages of Northern Australia: Comparative Studies of the Continent's Most Linguistically Complex Region, 369-421. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 085883538

ISBN 085883538

Green, Rebecca. 2003. Proto Maningrida within Proto Arnhem: Evidence from Verbal Inflectional Suffixes. In Nicholas Evans (ed.), The Non-Pama-Nyungan Languages of Northern Australia: Comparative Studies of the Continent's Most Linguistically Complex Region, 369-421. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 085883538

child.pub-comments: The author did not include this language in her reconstruction, but still indicates that she believes this language is part of Proto Arnhem. "I have not included data from the other languages on which AEH [Alpher, Evans, and Harvey] based their reconstruction (Dalabon, Bininj Gun-wok, Jawoyn, Ngalakgan, Warray and Uwinymil) only because they do not appear to have any reflexes of the suffixes which are the major focus of this paper. While displaying data from these languages would perhaps have given a clearer picture of the retention and loss of the posited proto-forms among the allleged daughter languages, it would have been largely repetitive of what is clearly shown in AEH, and would have made the current paper too bulky. I certainly am not excluding them from the language to which these paradigmatic irregularities are attributable. Given the geographic spread of these languages, I suggest the name Proto Arnhem for this proto-language" (Green 2003: 370-371). "This paper shows that much of what has been proposed for Proto Gunwinyguan verbs is attributable to the parent language of a much wider grouping of languages, which I have called Proto Arnhem… To what extent, then, does 'Gunwinyguan' form a distinct grouping characterised by identifiable innovations? And what other branches can be demonstrated on the same basis?" (Green 2003: 419).
child.publications: Green, Rebecca. 2003. Proto Maningrida within Proto Arnhem: Evidence from Verbal Inflectional Suffixes. In Nicholas Evans (ed.), The Non-Pama-Nyungan Languages of Northern Australia: Comparative Studies of the Continent's Most Linguistically Complex Region, 369-421. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 085883538

I certainly am not excluding them from the language to which these paradigmatic irregularities are attributable. Given the geographic spread of these languages, I suggest the name Proto Arnhem for this proto-language" (Green 2003: 370-371). "This paper shows that much of what has been proposed for Proto Gunwinyguan verbs is attributable to the parent language of a much wider grouping of languages, which I have called Proto Arnhem… To what extent, then, does 'Gunwinyguan' form a distinct grouping characterised by identifiable innovations?
